0.00.text:
Hello my name is Judy... my mother
passed away at the end of June this year,

14.28.text:
We suggested sheltered accommodation, a smaller house, and she was just adamant that she wanted
to stay here

19.66.text: because the house held for her all the memories of my father and us growing up.

25.40.text: As she grew older and into her eighties it became clear that all was not well, and she was diagnosed with dementia,

36.69.text: and from that organised for her to have three carers a day to come in and help with her food

43.84.text: and her personal care which became an issue. And so we went on for a few years like that,

53.04.text:
and mum would have episodes where her illness,
which wasn’t just dementia, but it was an

62.97.text: unconfirmed, I think is the word, pancreatic cancer, would result in her being jaundiced

77.66.text: Last summer she had a really bad episode with jaundice and became very ill. She ended up in hospital and it was clear by that stage

90.42.text:
that we couldn’t go on, that with three
or even four carers a day it wasn’t enough.

105.68.text: I had  a very open and honest conversation with her GP at the very outset and asked would it be possible for mum to die in her own home

117.49.text: which is inevitably what will happen, whatever the timescale is, and she said,

124.27.text: “I think we can do it, I think it’s possible.” And my experience of the process was that at every

133.14.text:
turn as mum deteriorated, I could ring the
surgery and ask for a conversation at any

141.05.text: time and she would obviously be with patients or in meetings but she would always say,

147.34.text:
"I will ring her back." And then I could talk
to her and say this is what’s happening with mum.

154.23.text: It became increasingly difficult to get her to the surgery - she was quite immobile at the end.

161.06.text: And she would listen to what I was saying and I would say, this is what I think is happening but I'm not sure.

170.56.text: And she would say" I think I’ll pop up, I’ll just pop up”. And she never once made me feel that I was making a fuss

179.55.text: she always had time and would ring back that day sometime. And it was just a grown-up

191.10.text: conversation about the well-being of a patient where I felt involved, I felt listened to,

198.72.text:
I felt mum was going to be cared
for in the very best way, and we were absolutely together

207.86.text: on what we were trying to achieve.

216.38.text: The last episode mum had in hospital,

219.46.text: she was deemed end-of-life and at that point was fast-tracked and had continuing healthcare

228.60.text:
I think it’s called. A lovely 24-hour carer
came, Sabrie, who was absolutely amazing.

236.11.text: And together we carried on, and Sabrie had a good relationship with the surgery as well

243.44.text: and knew she could ring them. The person I haven’t mentioned is Julie – I think she’s

250.41.text: the community nurse – she was always on hand.

255.82.text:
So towards the end of mum’s life and it
was becoming apparent, although one can never

260.96.text:
say when that’s going to be, that things
were declining, and a decision was taken about

267.52.text: the various medications she was taking, to pare down the medication to the essential

274.49.text: things that would contribute to her comfort rather than trying to treat underlying

283.09.text: causes of things but to keep her comfortable and pain free. Dr Williams was always assiduous

292.72.text:
in saying this is what I think will help her
to make her feel more comfortable, so that

299.65.text:
you give her the quality of life that’s
possible – that was always the goal.

307.24.text: So I felt very blessed, really, that she would be someobody who would look at it that way

316.26.text: so she wasn’t over-treating her but nor was she under-treating her.

322.18.text: And so we went on with Julie coming almost every day at times and supporting Sabrie the carer. We had medication delivered from the

334.18.text: pharmacy so there was that connection with the surgery and prescriptions, it all worked really well.

343.34.text:
And then, towards the very end
morphine was administered orally, in tablet form

352.12.text:
in slow release and very little was
needed. As far as we know mum never had any pain

358.99.text: which is amazing and as it should be.

371.00.text:
and I count it a huge privilege – it’s a profound moment
to be with someone when she dies.

382.28.text:
We called in to see her – we were going
to Devon for the weekend and I had a moment

387.66.text:
where mum came back to me and we had a couple
of hours together looking at all her photos

392.66.text:
and it was wonderful, a real miracle she just
kind of came back really. And we went to Devon

399.45.text:
and I was waiting for a phone call but it
didn’t come and then coming back we called

405.97.text: in again so it was two days later and I could see things had changed and she was slipping away.

413.18.text:
Her breathing became very laboured and
every breath was like a groan and it was horrible...it was horrible.

422.78.text:
I called the doctor and she
said she thought it was a reflex, not pain.

434.64.text:
She talked me through what might happen at
the end, things that may worry me such as

442.94.text:
taking breath and stop and then another breath.
That last night was horrible, it was horrible.

452.54.text:
Sabrie said “you go to bed, I’ll take
first shift.” We got a mattress down with

457.51.text: mum and Sabrie was on the floor and I woke up in the middle of the night and went down

461.59.text: and sat with them both. Sabrie was asleep and I just sat there, every breath seemed

466.21.text:
like an effort, massive effort and the next
day it was still going on and it was Sabrie’s

472.92.text:
day off and I said “you go.” So she went
and Julie was here, came up, and there was

482.81.text:
another carer who stepped in as Sabrie’s
replacement and people were coming and going

489.49.text:
and at lunchtime, Julie came back with the
Marie Curie nurse and I said “we haven’t

498.00.text:
checked her pads can you just check, I’m
not sure I’m doing the right thing.”

502.14.text:
And they bathed her together – it was beautiful,
they were so gentle and they just washed her

512.20.text:
gently and they changed her. It was like an
anointing – it was just beautiful.

522.28.text:
I knew she wasn’t in pain any more. Her
breathing had settled and she was just lying

528.11.text:
there and said, I was holding and stroking
her arms and I said "I think she’s going",

534.34.text: because the circulation starts to go and her hands went purple and this went on for so

544.55.text: many hours I can’t quite remember and into the early evening. I rang Sabrie, who was still out

550.89.text:
on her day off and said if you want to be
here you need to come back.

556.32.text: So she came straight back...and...we prayed together, and read the Bible and I just said “you can go,” just stroking

576.58.text:
her face, “you can go, they’re all waiting.
You know, Jesus is waiting and all your family

585.97.text: that have gone before, and they will say ‘here comes Molly.’” And she just gently slipped

591.62.text: away and it was so beautiful, and there was no rattling breathing, and none of the things

598.51.text:
that Dr Williams warned me about, she just
left and her mouth was closed, her eyes were

606.62.text:
closed, there was nothing traumatic in any
way, it was so beautiful.

612.52.text: And it’s like a birth, it’s that profound, you see somebody depart.

623.46.text:
You know what’s left is a shell, and
the body starts to deteriorate almost instantly

631.16.text:
and you’re left with this...it’s not my
mum any more.

641.96.text: They have an end-of-life meeting, and there are people on that list and they have a sort

649.40.text:
of traffic light system I gather, so that
people who are critical and some people who are lower

657.76.text:
down on the list. But it seems to me that
that must be working.

664.50.text: They did say "your mother goes up and down the traffic lights. Sometimes she's on red alert other times, amber!"

671.94.text: But I think because they must be meeting as a team with the district nurses,

676.56.text: the Marie Curie nurses, the GP, I’m not quite sure who was involved

682.67.text:
in those meetings but it seemed to me that
that underpins the joined-up care that I felt

689.89.text: mum was getting and I felt that we were getting. The other thing they seemed to do extremely
